name: Bridging Words & Visions
description: What happens when language becomes a visual experience? Artist Ravikumar Kashi and poet Mamta Sagar delve into this question, exploring how text generates visuals and how Kashi's work transforms text into art. Their conversation will trace the connections between the written word and the visual image, offering unique insights from two distinct artistic perspectives.

name: Paper, Language, and Us
description:
Beyond ink and words, paper itself becomes art in Ravikumar Kashi's We don't end at our edges. 

Ravikumar Kashi is a Bengaluru-based artist, writer and educator whose practice revolves around exploring the mechanics of meaning-making. We don’t end at our edges is an immersive exhibition featuring his artworks. He uses paper to ‘paint’ letters from the Kannada alphabet, transforming language itself into a metaphor for the permeability of human connection, suggesting that while physical forms may fade, the bonds we share as individuals and as a community remain.

Join us for a conversation between MAP’s Collections Manager Rucha Vibhute and Ravikumar Kashi as they explore various aspects of his work, inspiration behind his art and more.

name: Reading Images, Writing Gender
description:
Reading and writing are verbs we use to describe texts. What if we deploy these terms to images, and to how we interpret them? What would that gesture look and feel like? Would it enhance or deplete our aesthetic experience?

Come explore a sociological perspective of our permanent exhibition, VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection with Dr Gita Chadha, a feminist sociologist who will take us through how we might read and write meanings to the artworks. Come prepared with your thoughts on art, gender and the relationship between the two!

name: Mark-making
description:
Mark-making—the use of lines, dots, patterns, and textures in art—ranges from loose, gestural strokes to tight, controlled details. It is a deeply personal and instinctive process, with every mark carrying energy, emotion, and intention. This hands-on workshop led by Sindhu Kulkarni, explores the expressive potential of mark-making as a fundamental element of visual storytelling and design. Participants will engage in guided exercises that encourage spontaneity, rhythm, and composition through diverse tools and materials. The session will focus on the physicality of marks—how gestures, textures, and repetition contribute to form and meaning

There are no right or wrong marks, only discoveries waiting to unfold. As you explore different tools and surfaces, you’ll find that each stroke adds to your visual language, shaping how you see and express the world around you. 

Designed for artists, designers, and creative enthusiasts, this workshop invites you to experiment freely, embrace the unexpected, and discover new ways of seeing and creating.

This workshop is part of the opening of We Don’t End At Our Edges exhibition programming.

name: Artist & Curator-led Guided Walk
description:
"I work with paper and not on paper."

We don’t end at our edges is an immersive exhibition featuring artworks by Bengaluru-based artist, writer and educator Ravikumar Kashi. He uses paper to ‘paint’ letters from the Kannada alphabet, transforming language itself into a metaphor for the permeability of human connection, suggesting that while physical forms may fade, the bonds we share as individuals and as a community remain.

Join us for a guided walk of the exhibition, led by the artist and the curator Khushi Bansal.

name: DEEP SEE- A Framed Moment Never Tells The Full Story.
description:
Join us for an evening of art, vision, and conversation as designer Janak Mistry sits down with Rustam Vania to discuss DEEP SEE — a captivating visual journey through India’s vibrant diversity.

What began as casual snapshots on the streets over a decade ago with Janak Mistry’s first smartphone has evolved into a book reflecting various perspectives.

In DEEP SEE, Janak Mistry captures ordinary sights to encourage people to discover the extraordinary in the everyday. All images in this book were taken with a mobile phone, focusing not on perfection but on seizing fleeting moments. The book showcases a unique vision that transforms the mundane into the remarkable, with playful, nonlinear texts revealing multiple layers of reality in each image.

Be part of a thought-provoking conversation on art, vision, and the power of mobile photography.

name: Community Check-in
description:
Join us for a creative and collaborative community check-in session inspired by artworks from the MAP's collection. In this interactive event, you'll be assigned to small groups and asked to craft a poem or short story based on the imagery or themes from the V/IV exhibition provided. After some time to collaborate and create, each group will have the opportunity to present their work to the rest of the participants. This session invites you to explore art, storytelling, and connection in a fun and engaging way.

This session will be in conjunction with VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women in Art through the MAP Collection.

Limited seats available—register now to confirm your spot!  

This programme is exclusively for 18–25 year olds.

This session is conducted as part of our engagements for the MAP Youth Collective. The MAP Youth Collective is a community for young people (18-25 year olds) to engage with the arts and culture sector. The collective is for, of, and by young people — to explore our shared identities and interests through art.

name: Visual Storage Guided Walk
description: Museums are like icebergs – what you see on display is just the tip! Dive deeper into our collection with a guided walk of our visual storage by Rayna Rocha from the MAP Collections team. Learn more about our MAP archives and witness the sheer volume of art and artefacts carefully preserved. In this session you can learn about the challenges of storage, the importance of conservation, and the surprising discoveries that await within our hidden spaces in the museum.

name: ISL Guided Walk
description:
Ever thought of paper as the artwork, and not just the medium?

We don’t end at our edges is an immersive exhibition featuring artworks by Bengaluru-based artist, writer and educator Ravikumar Kashi. He uses paper to ‘paint’ letters from the Kannada alphabet, transforming language itself into a metaphor for the permeability of human connection, suggesting that while physical forms may fade, the bonds we share as individuals and as a community remain.

Join us for a guided walk of the exhibition by the artist Ravikumar Kashi, specially curated for deaf and hard of hearing (HH) community with ISL interpreters.

name: Artist-led Guided Walk
description:
"I work with paper and not on paper."

We don’t end at our edges is an immersive exhibition featuring artworks by Bengaluru-based artist, writer and educator Ravikumar Kashi. He uses paper to ‘paint’ letters from the Kannada alphabet, transforming language itself into a metaphor for the permeability of human connection, suggesting that while physical forms may fade, the bonds we share as individuals and as a community remain.

Join us for a guided walk in Kannada and English of the exhibition, led by the artist.
